column32: All analyses were conducted using R v 4.2.1 (R Core Team, 2022). Packages used for analyses included ‘car’ (v 3.1–0) to determine VIFs for each predictor (Fox & Weisberg, 2019), ‘lme4’ (v 1.1–29; Bates et al., 2015), ‘glmmTMB’ (v 1.1.3; Brooks et al., 2017) and ‘zoib’ (v 1.5.5; Liu & Kong, 2015), to build our GLMMs, ‘lmtest’ (v 0.9–40) to conduct our likelihood ratio tests (Zeileis & Hothorn, 2022), ‘MuMIN’ (v 1.46.0) for model selection (Bartoń, 2023), ‘DHARMa’ (v 0.4.5) for model validation (Florian & Lukas, 2022) and ‘spaa’ (v 0.2.2) and ‘cluster’ (v 2.1.4) to determine the niche widths and overlaps (Maechler et al., 2023; Zhang & Ma, 2022)

column32: Three-way repeated-measures analysis of variance (ANOVA) was conducted with SOC and SON data from field experiment 1, and one-way repeated-measures ANOVA was conducted on all other data using SPSS 19 (SPSS Inc.). The data for each treatment comprised of three replicates. Least significance difference (LSD, p < 0.05) analysis was used for the mean significance test of each experiment (Guo et al., 2016; Hu et al., 2013). The yield and N2 fixation data in beans are the averages of data from 2016 to 2017, and figures were generated using Origin 2019 (Originlab Corp.).

column32: we applied multi-state mark–recapture models to 8 years of intensive year-round resighting data from colour-ringed juvenile choughs to quantify variable juvenile exposure to management within and among years, and to estimate management efficacy in increasing within-year and annual juvenile survival. We then combined these estimates within matrix population projections to estimate overall impacts of the 8-year intervention on population size.

column32: We used a generalised linear mixed effect model (GLMM) to test the factors contributing to the ability of Philophthalmus to prevent invasion by the competitor Maritrema. The model had a binomial error structure as the response variable, that is, whether or not a snail becomes infected by Maritrema, had a success/failure binary format. This model was constructed using the glmer function in the r package lme4 (Bates, Maechler, Bolker, & Walker, 2015). Fixed effects were Maritrema exposure level (control, low, medium and high) and presence/absence of a Philophthalmus colony in the snail. The interaction between exposure level and Philophthalmus colony presence/absence was removed during model construction based on model diagnostics and relative AIC values. Container number was also included as a random effect to control for potential differences among snail groups. p-values were calculated using the F-statistic and F-numerator generated by the GLMM described above and the F-denominator value from a general linear model (function glm in the r package stats) of the same structure as the GLMM, but without the random effect of tank number. Post hoc analysis was conducted using the ghlt function in the r package multcomp (Hothorn, Bretz, & Westfall, 2008).

This paper is a Research Article, but describing an R package, so I treated it as an application paper.
The archived code provided is useless, and contains things such as data reading functions leading to a local folder... BUT the code now available on CRAN is good. The package was submitted to CRAN after MEE acceptance. I assessed the archived code and data, not the currently available version on CRAN.

column32: We performed all statistical analyses using r version 3.1.1 (R Core Team, 2014) and the lme4 package (Bates, Maechler, Bolker, & Walker, 2015). As our experimental design used blocks, we worked with mixed models, always utilizing tree pair as random factor and including soil temperature and density of conspecific seedlings as covariables as they could influence seedling mortality, budburst delay, leaf herbivory, mycorrhization and fungal-driven decomposition. The adequacy of models to data was always checked graphically with residuals-vs.-fitted values plot and QQ plot of the residuals. Variance explained by each model was estimated by calculating the marginal R2 (i.e. variance explained by fixed factors only) and the conditional R2 (i.e. variance explained by both fixed and random factors) (Nakagawa & Schielzeth, 2013).

column35: Model selection, model-averaging, and assessment of variable importance were performed using the MuMIn package (Barton, 2013) using R v.3.2.0 (R Core Team, 2015).  Using RAMAS GIS software v6.0 (Akçakaya & Root, 2013), temporal trends in adult and senescent adult survival rates were specified as time series of relative changes in survival estimates. Further details including parameterization of the climate-driven PVA model and model validation data and methods are in the Supplementary Information.  We identified important modelled interactions by quantifying the strength of pairwise interactions while keeping nonfocal variables at their mean values. Implementation of the BRT model was performed in R v.3.3.0 (R Core Team, 2015) using the gbm package (Greg Ridgeway with contributions from others , 2015).

column13: If these questions aim to get at parachute science there are two important things to note: 1) the authors of interest my be from the culture, community, or georegion under study and may be working elsewhere, and 2) researchers can be from the same georegion under study and still be conducting parachute science (e.g., this happens often in the US for historically minoritized communities such as Black and Indigenous communities with white and Westernized science; and there may be socially constructed hierarchies within the same georegion contributing to parachute science).

AND
Analyses were performed in R (R Development Core Team, 2011).

column32:
These were compared between populations using generalised linear models followed by Tukey's pairwise comparisons using function glht from the r package multcomp (Hothorn et al., 2008).
We tested for differences among functional groups of pollinators using analysis of variance and running paired Tukey tests in the base package in r.

We fitted GAM models using the mgcv package in r (Wood, 2011), and then calculated the statistical significance of selection coefficients via the bootstrap approach (N > 500 iterations) implemented in package gsg (Morrissey & Sakrejda, 2014). Standardisation of traits and fitness values, as well as scaling of quadratic coefficients (as explained in Stinchcombe et al., 2008), are automatically implemented by the ‘gsg’ calculations.

column32: Analyses were done with R 4.1.0 (R Core Team, 2021). We used the lme4 package to adjust the models and the lmerTest package to calculate the significance of the fixed effects of GLMM with the Satterthwaite method (Bates et al., 2015; Kuznetsova et al., 2017). We estimated the R2 value of the fixed and random effects with the MuMIn package (Barton, 2019). Data wrangling operations were done with base R coding and fitdistrplus, dplyr and tidyr packages (Delignette-Muller & Dutang, 2015; Wickham et al., 2020; Wickham & Henry, 2020). The R code used is available in Appendix S7.

column48:
To correctly run Haplostrips you will need: - Python pandas package version 0.17.0 or newer

If you want to use tabix indexing to retrieve windows faster: - Python pysam package Automatically used if it finds .tbi files, to avoid this please rename the .tbi files involved.

Dependencies need pip Python package manager to be installed. If you do not have it on your system or you are not sure please visit:

https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/installing/
column59: This was an application paper where the authors used existing data to perform analyses to have a plot output. This analysis was the main outcome of the paper that was made into a software. The authors used existing data, the link for which was reported in the 'Data Accessibility Statement'. Since the data was not the outcome of the research, but was archived, I had trouble responding to section 2 and 3. In addition, the code was not mentioned anywhere but in the 'Conclusion' section since it was the main outcome of the paper and was archived. This was however difficult to comprehend despite the detailed ReadMe file. This was especially the case due to lack of sample data in the code repository and the incompatibility of my Windows system to run the code without compressing and decompressing the data

column59: Fifth paper I did. I took 16 minutes, in case that is useful. I feel it is important to note that the data has metadata but not a README or a data dictionary/codebook. The metadata provided is perfect, but since there is no README or data dictionary, I decided not to answer question 9. The authors provide data in an institutional repository. Since the repository does not display citations, I went to DataCite to figure it out (https://commons.datacite.org/?query=10.25829%2Fidiv.1915-15-3293). It is important to note that one of the dataset they say to provide cannot be downloaded (BEF-China website FoliarFungi2014 https://data.botanik.uni-halle.de/bef-china/datasets/635), which is why I chose “Some analyses can be repeated but not all (~50% of analyses can be repeated).” But answer the other data questions based on the dataset that was provided (iDiv Biodiversity Data Portal (iBDP) https://doi.org/10.25829/idiv.1915-15-3293).

column32:
In the dryad repositery: "This is the code and data that generates the models and figures used in the manuscript and supplementary documents.

We begin by generating an ensemble of models for each transition matrix, which are associated with the same dynamic behaviours determined through expert elicitation. To do this we first determine a scalar multiple for each transition matrix, that will be multiplied along the diagonal of the coefficient matrix and ensure that one thousand models are generated in approximately 24 hours. This is done using the Matlab script FindMultiplier.m in which a user selects the transition matrix to investigate (and its type: 1 if all signs are defined, 2 if the sign is uncertain)."

column32: We evaluated chain convergence using the R package Coda (Plummer et al., 2006). The models were implemented in program JAGS (Plummer, 2003) that we executed from R (R Core Team, 2019) with the package r2 jags (Su & Yajima, 2012). ... Bayesian survival trajectory analyses implemented in the R package BaSTA were used to estimate those mortality metrics (Colchero & Clark, 2012; Colchero et al., 2012). ... The outputted vcf file was further filtered using python and bash scripts from the stacks workflow RAD-seq pipeline analysis available online (https://github.com/enormandeau/stacks_workflow). ... The parameters were calculated using a custom python script (available at https://github.com/enormandeau/stacks_workflow) parsing the filtered VCF file. ... Normalization was performed using the trimmed mean of M-values method originally described for RNA-seq count normalization and implemented in the R package edgeR (Robinson & Oshlack, 2010). ... All statistical tests were implemented in Scipy v.1.5.1 in Python 3.6.3. ... We also calculated pairwise FST using the R library StAMPP (Pembleton et al., 2013) with 95% CI estimated on 1,000 bootstraps. ... We tested for linear correlations between allele frequencies and mean annual temperature using latent factor mixed models implemented in the R package lfmm 2 (Caye et al., 2019). ... For the 20 strongest CNV loci putatively associated with temperature (those with highest R2), we examined whether discrete copy number categories could be drawn from the distributions of normalized read depth using a model-based unsupervised clustering approach implemented in the R library Mclust, V. 5.4.4 (Fraley et al., 2012).

column7: The species location data used to build the SDMs has not been publicly archived as it details sensitive information related to the location of species at risk. Data are held in the NHIC of Ontario, of the Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry. These data are available from the NHIC but only after appropriate training and signing of data sharing agreements with provincial authorities. Inquiries about obtaining a Sensitive Data Use License can be sent by e-mail to NHICrequests@ontario.ca or by phone 705-755-2159. Due to privacy concerns, information on property ownership and value have not been archived. These data are accessible via GeoWarehouse (https://www2.geowarehouse.ca; 1-866-237-5937) or the appropriate land registry office (https://www.ontario.ca/page/land-registry-offices-lro). column7: For this work, and in an effort to create a diverse and statistically substantial dataset, we aggregated more than 60,000 images of fish specimens from five ichthyological research collections (Field Museum of Natural History (http://www.tubri.org/HDR/FMNH/), Illinois Natural History Survey (http://www.tubri.org/HDR/INHS/), J. F. Bell Museum of Natural History (http://www.tubri.org/HDR/JFBM/), Ohio State University Museum of Biological Diversity (http://www.tubri.org/HDR/OSUM/) and the University of Wisconsin-Madison Zoological Museum (http://www.tubri.org/HDR/UWZM/)) that participated in the Great Lakes Invasives Network Project (GLIN) (http://greatlakesinvasives.org/). The GLIN project is digitizing 1.73 million historical biological specimens representing 2,550 species, including fishes, clams, snails, mussels, algae and plants that are potentially invasive to the Great Lakes Region of the U.S. The computer code used for running our experiments is found at Elhamod et al. (2021).

column59: Sixth paper I did. I took 24 minutes, in case that is useful. The repository is huge and it is not easy to say what is data and what is something else. The README (.md) is not really informative, though there seem to be files here and there with a lot of information. In the repository, there are other files that might be data, such as .js or .geojson, but I cannot really say. The data folder contains many files in various formats, some of which I cannot open. The README is not informative, so assessing the completeness of the archived data is virtually impossible without running all the code. The authors provide data and code in the same Zenodo repository. Since Zenodo does not display citations, I went to DataCite to figure it out (https://commons.datacite.org/?query=10.5281%2Fzenodo.4721426). This is possibly the most difficult paper of all six papers I have done so far. Assessing the completeness of the data is really not possible without an excessive time investment, and, from our experiences in previous similar projects, only possible once you attempt to run the code.

column13:
Some samples were collected in Germany but this is ex situ to the zebras' native habitat which can misrepresent equity as the former is a wealthier country.
  
Some samples were collected in South Africa, the country of origin of their zebras, and there was an author based in that georegion. However, South Africa's colonial history means this may misrepresent equity as the research may be divorced from the local population. 

The samples were collected in different countries to the authors but the authors analysed the data in their locality of the UK, meaning the data theoretically originates in the UK. However, this should still mean the authors' country differs to where the 'data' originated.

column32: e used the functions ‘lmer’ for the models and ‘glht’ for the posthoc tests from the r packages lme4 and multcomp, respectively (Bates et al., 2012; Hothorn et al., 2008). To calculate temporal beta-diversity indices, we used the function ‘TBI’ (Legendre & De Caceres, 2013) from the package adespatial (Dray et al., 2019). To assess whether compositional dissimilarity of vascular epiphyte assemblages, as variation in assemblage dissimilarity independent from differences in alpha diversity, was related to differences in host tree sizes (DBH), we ran a mantel test (function ‘mantel.test’) using the r package ape (Paradis & Schliep, 2019), with 999 permutations. To assess whether compositional dissimilarity of epiphyte assemblages was spatially structured, we ran a mantel correlogram (function ‘mantel.correlog’) using the r package ncf (Bjornstad, 2020).To test whether mean Raup-Crick values deviated significantly from 0, we used the sign-test and the command ‘SIGN.test’ from the r package bsda (Arnholt & Evans, 2017).

column32: The material from the interviews was analysed using NVivo (v.12) software. The transcripts of the interviews were imported into NVivo and coded, using different ‘nodes’ which represent the variables relevant to the study aims (Ishak & Bakar, 2012). A total of 39 nodes and 88 sub-nodes were used in the analysis (see Annex 2 in Supplementary Material for full list of the nodes and sub-nodes). While having so many nodes and sub-nodes presented a small risk of lack of consistency in coding, it was best suited to analyse the extensive qualitative material gathered.

The PSPManalysis package is available on CRAN (https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=PSPManalysis) and can be installed and subsequently loaded using the commands:


install.packages("PSPManalysis")

library(PSPManalysis)

After loading the package, all computations necessary to reproduce the figures presented in this paper can be executed step-by-step by executing the following demo() command:


demo("Salmon", package = "PSPManalysis", echo = FALSE)

No data have been used in this paper, other than the contents of the PSPManalysis package available on CRAN.

column32: We determined population genetic structure using a PCA of Euclidian genetic distances based on allele frequencies, generated with the R package Adegenet (Jombart, 2008). We then ran a discriminant analysis of the principal components (DAPC) to identify the optimal discriminant axes that maximise the between-group variation while minimising the within-group variation. In addition, we used admixture analysis to generate ancestry coefficient plots with the snmf function in the R package LEA (Frichot & François, 2015). We identified the number of population clusters existing in our dataset based on cross-entropy values and plot visualisation. We tested a range of 1–10 population clusters and ran five replicates for each.

column59: Seventh paper I did. I took 28 minutes, in case that is useful. This is a bit of a tricky case. The authors developed a framework, but in the process, they performed a literature review, integrated expert knowledge via surveys, and developed a summary and a synthesis across studies. The authors, however, write “The manuscript does not include any primary data.”, which I do not think is at all correct. Regarding the country where the study was performed, as far as I can understand, all people surveyed are from Germany, but that is not clear, and the authors do not provide information on that. Though the paper could have used code for some of the tasks, it all indicates that it did not.

column32: Correlations between hydraulic traits were calculated by using the package ‘Hmisc’ (biostat.mc.vanderbilt.edu/Hmisc) with the R-project version 3.6.2 (https://www.r-project.org/). Only if the p value was smaller than 0.05, the correlations were considered to be statistically significant. Principal Component Analysis (PCA) of 16 traits was conducted by using the ‘vegan’ package (Dixon, 2003). The relationship between species loadings on the first component and relative altitude of individual species was analysed with a linear regression in SigmaPlot 12.5.

column59: Eight paper I did. I took 11 minutes, in case that is useful. column7: The source code to our visualiser and associated server software is freely downloadable from https://github.com/OneZoom/. OneZoom version 3.5 ‘Chocolate chip starfish’, incorporating all tree of life data that we have permission to redistribute, is available in a Docker container hosted on Zenodo (OneZoom Core Team, 2021b). These data include phylogenetic data from the Open Tree of Life and elsewhere, images and vernacular names harvested from the Encyclopedia of Life and elsewhere, and data derived from Wikidata and Wikipedia database dumps. IUCN data are not included, but the Docker container includes a tool to automatically download the most up to date IUCN data via their public API. Readers should note that the OneZoom software and underlying data are provided under a variety of licenses which are not necessarily the same as the license of this article. These licenses are noted within the distributed software.

contains Statement on Inclusion: 
STATEMENT ON INCLUSION

Our study failed to include local researchers and stakeholders. The Trinidad system has had many diverse research teams that, in the past, have successfully included local scientists and graduate students from the University of West Indies. However, time and funding were both limiting factors for this project. We realize that we could have made better efforts to reach out and include these scientists. We plan to mitigate this and reach out to local scientists for future projects.

column32:
Intraspecific trait variation was quantified in relation to population source (cultivar or local ecotype plots) by comparing standardized effect sizes (SES) of T-statistics calculated from testing the departure of observed trait distributions from randomized trait distributions (n = 99 permutations) using the Tstats function in the cati R package (Taudiere & Violle, 2016). 

A comparison of mean functional trait values of each species in cultivar versus local ecotype treatments were compared using one-way ANOVA in SAS (SAS Institute, 2011).

column32:
All analyses were performed in R, version 1.4.1717. The significance of fixed effects in linear mixed models (LMER) was calculated from F statistics with the ‘lmerTest’ package and Satterthwaite's approximation to calculate the denominator degrees of freedom. The significance of fixed effects in generalized linear mixed models (GLMER) was calculated from chi-square statistics, using Wald chi-square tests from the ‘car’ package. The distribution of residuals from the models was checked to ensure model assumptions were met and corrections for overdispersion were made when needed.

Using ImageJ analysis software (https://imagej.nih.gov/ij/index.html) from those photographs, we measured male's body size (standard length, SL, in mm; distance from the snout to the base of the caudal fin). Body size was used with body weight to quantify a male's body condition (i.e. his fat stores or surplus energy) using Fulton's body condition index (Kotrschal et al., 2011).

column32: With the exception of the Katz metric, which was calculated using a custom R code written by the second author, the other metrics were calculated using the R package bipaRtite (Dormann, 2011). So, we calculated the evolutionary distinctive-ness (ED; typically quantified using phylogenetic branch lengths)for each species using the Equal Splits measure implemented in the function evol.distinct from the R package picante (Kembelet al., 2010). The IVI is a combination of six metrics: degree,cluster rank, local H index, neighbourhood connectivity, between-ness and collective influence. IVI was calculated with the R package influential (Salavaty et al., 2020). To assess the role of different trait variables in explaining spe-cies centrality, we applied Bayesian GLMMs (Table S1), which usesMarkov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods to obtain the models'likelihood to non-Gaussian data. We used the function MCMCglmmimplemented in the R package McMcglMM (Hadfield, 2010).

column55:
the code uses a lot of field specific packages, which are being loaded a bit randomly in different parts of the process. It would help if there was a header with a list of all the packages needed, or some code checking which packages need to be installed (I had to rerun the code several times to discover all the packages I was missing).
This is typically the kind of work that would benefit a lot from using targets or at least be organised in a Rmd or qmd document. Overall the code was not very well organised.
Some parts were broken, but I am quite sure it is because the packages they used have been updated and/or because I did not run it as its own project and environment (I could easily fix it and make it run).

column32: Hue refers to the tone of colour, for example red, green and blue, which is evaluated by the wavelength of half-maximum reflectance, using the R package pavo (Maia et al., 2019). The relative intensity of a secondary peak (SP) was quantified by the ratio between the height of the SP and the height of the entire spectrum (following Chen, Niu, et al., 2020). Moreover, phylogenetic principal component analysis (PCA) was conducted (using the phyl.pca function in the R package phytools; Revell, 2012) on the spectral data to construct a spectral space, in which the comparison between flowers and fruits was made.

column32:
NOT ALL OF THE CODE IS ARCHIVED:
 To compare the data matrices, we performed multiple response permutation procedure (MRPP) with the R-package vegan (v.2.5-6; https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=vegan ) in R (version 3.6.0; RCoreTeam, 2020).
Principal coordinate analysis (PCoA) was calculated using R version 4.0.4 by using the function ‘pco’ in the package ecodist: (v. 2.0.7), using the data matrix of the metabolomics dataset with ‘Bray–Curtis’ as dissimilarity measure. The distance matrix was calculated using the package vegan (v. 2.5-7) and the function ‘vegdist’. PERMANOVA was calculated using the ‘adonis2’ function in vegan with ‘Bray–Curtis’ as distance measure.

column32:
We tested differences in grass cover, volume and patch size across the treatments and plot sizes using a Kruskal–Wallis and Dunn's post hoc comparison test (Dunn, 1961). We also calculated the effect size of the Kruskal–Wallis test (Kotrlik & Williams, 2003) based on the H-statistic to determine the percentage of variance in the vegetation metrics explained by the treatment effect using the R package rstatix (Kassambara, 2020). The H-statistic was interpreted as follows: values >0.01 but <0.06 (small effect), >0.06 but <0.14 (moderate effect) and ≥0.14 (large effect). We used kernel density estimation (plotted in the R package ggplot2, R Core Team, 2021) to compare the distribution of grass height and short grass patch sizes across the fire treatments.

To evaluate the spatial continuity of short grasses patches, we constructed semivariograms in the gstat R package (Pebesma & Graeler, 2023).

column7: The data is not readily available online. We took this measure aiming to respect the autonomy of the community and prioritize the protection of privacy and cultural sensitivities. The data used in this paper was collected on the Collective Land of Ipetí Emberá and thus belongs to the community. Moreover, some species planted have a high commercial value, and neighbouring communities have had issues with illegal harvesting. We thus encourage researchers seeking access to data collected within the collective land of Ipetí Emberá to reach out to the local authorities of the Alto Bayano Congreso.

column7:
The dataset and the R/Stan codes used in the case study (Section 4.3) can be found in the repository https://github.com/EdgarSantos-Fernandez/hakuna. These files have been archived on Zenodo (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.4702772, Santos-Fernandez) and the latest released version can be found in https://zenodo.org/badge/latestdoi/353582115. See other examples in https://github.com/EdgarSantos-Fernandez/staircase.

The following files are part of the repository:
serengeti.RDS: contains the Serengeti dataset.
Item_response_modeling_for_big_data.Rmd: this R markdown file includes the full R/Stan codes for fitting the models, combining the posterior estimates and for visualizing the results.
Item_response_modeling_for_big_data.pdf: this is the knitted R markdown output file.

column32:
Because hidden state models require a regular sampling unit, location and altitude data were linearly interpolated in R with custom code to a constant one-minute temporal resolution (R Development Core Team, 2016)

The model was fitted using JAGS run from R (package runjags; Supporting Information Appendix S2) (Denwood, 2016). 

The R package coda was used to assess convergence, calculate effective sample size and extract posterior estimates (Plummer, Best, Cowles, & Vines, 2006).

column32: To examine the effects of landscape on the number of workers, larvae and provisions in a colony, we compared models containing the first two principal components using Akaike's information criterion adjusted for sample size (AICc) with the model.sel function in the MuMIn package (Barton, 2019). The fixed effects for these four models included: (a) Sampling period only, (b) Sampling period + PC1, (c) Sampling period + PC2 and (d) Sampling period + PC1 + PC2. We included the random effect of site in all models, fit models with a negative binomial distribution using the glmer.nb function in the lme4 package (Bates, Mächler, Bolker, & Walker, 2014), and analysed models for the worker, larval and provisions datasets separately.

Count data are archived by Sovon, and available upon request. The volunteers who contributed to the monthly goose counts collectively own these data, and since it contains detailed locations of wintering geese, it will not be made publicly available. Contact details: menno.hornman@sovon.nl, Dutch Centre For Field Ornithology (Sovon), Toernooiveld 1, 6525 ED Nijmegen, Netherlands.

The GPS tracks are available through Movebank (www.movebank.org) in the study ‘GPS data from: More grazing, more damage? Assessed yield loss on agricultural grassland relates non-linearly to goose grazing pressure’, published in the Movebank Data Repository https://doi.org/10.5441/001/1.fk899541 (Buitendijk et al., 2022).

column32: The split-plot ANOVAs were performed using the “aov” function in the base package of r. The code used in r was “aov(Variable~N_Level*Plant_Removal+Error(Block/N_Level)),” where Variable was the response variable, N_Level was a factor with six levels (Level1 to Level6 for 0, 1.75, 5.25, 10.50, 17.5 and 28.0 g of N m−2 year−1, respectively), Plant_Removal was binary (0 = with plant, 1 = without plant), and Block was an integer (1–5 for spatial blocks).

column32: Expression values generated by edgeR were used for examining profiles of expression across different samples through a hierarchical clustering. A heatmap of DEGs was generated using the heatmap3 package in r v3.2.2 (R Core Team, 2015). To assess overall similarity across samples, their relationships were also explored through a PCA on the transposed normalized expression matrix with r v3.2.2. Venn diagrams to identify shared and unique DEGs between different contrasts were performed with http://bioinformatics.psb.ugent.be/webtools/Venn/. GO-term enrichment analysis of DEGs was performed through the Fisher's exact test approach by using the GO enrichment analysis function provided by Blast2GO v.5 with a threshold FDR of 0.05. Due to a large list of enriched GO terms was obtained in SAM comparisons, a further reduction to most specific terms (FDR < 0.01) was carried out. Summarization and visualization of GO terms were performed by using the REVIGO web service (http://revigo.irb.hr/; Supek, Bošnjak, Škunca, & Šmuc, 2011).

column32:
Data were analysed using (generalised) linear mixed-effects models ([G]LMMs) using the ‘lme4’ package (Bates et al., 2015) in ‘r’ (R Core Team, 2020) and 95% confidence intervals for parameter estimates were generated by bootstrapping (1,000 samples using ‘bootMer’ [‘lme4’ package]).

Using ‘ict.test’ (r package ‘list’; Blair & Imai, 2010), we found no evidence of a design effect (p values between 0.31–1 for each list item; Whytock et al., 2018).

We tested for the effect of illegal offtake and return rate on measures of population growth and extinction probability using generalised additive models (GAMs, using Gaussian and binomial error structures for growth and extinction probability respectively; r package ‘mgcv’; Wood, 2011). All analyses were carried out in r (R Core Team, 2020).

column32:
3 Statistical analysis

We used modified binomial power analyses to assess our ability to detect P. destructans arrival at each site where no positive samples were detected. We first calculated an expected early prevalence at each site where P. destructans was not detected in early hibernation based on a weighted mean prevalence. The weighted mean prevalence was calculated as the average prevalence of each species at sites where P. destructans was detected in early hibernation multiplied by the proportional abundance of a given species at each site (Table S1). We then calculated the probability of missing P. destructans at a site as the probability of getting all negatives in bats given the expected prevalence at a site multiplied by the probability of missing P. destructans in the unsampled bats (calculation shown in Appendix S1).

We investigated the effect of timing of P. destructans arrival on late winter prevalence by fitting a GLMM with a binomial distribution and a logit link. We included fixed effects for the timing of P. destructans detection (early or late hibernation) interacting with the effect of species, and included site as a random effect. We also examined the effect of timing of P. destructans detection on fungal loads using a linear mixed model with species and timing of detection as interacting fixed effects, and site as a random effect. Lastly, we assessed the effect of the timing of P. destructans introduction on log10 bat population growth rates, calculated as the annual change in late winter counts at each site, using linear mixed models with species interacting with timing of detection as fixed effects and site as a random effect. We explored the inclusion of autumn prevalence as a continuous variable (0 for all sites and species where P. destructans was not detected, prevalence in each species ranged between 0 and 0.25 for sites where P. destructans was detected during autumn) and the results were qualitatively similar to those shown, so we present the discretization (early or late winter P. destructans detection) for simplicity of visualization and interpretation.

Lastly, we investigated evidence of overwinter movements of bats among sites. At each site, we calculated our response variable, overwinter urn:x-wiley:00218790:media:jane13439:jane13439-math-0001 as the proportional change in the number of bats of each species at a site by dividing the late hibernation count by the early hibernation count. We then used a linear mixed model to assess the relationship between log10(overwinter urn:x-wiley:00218790:media:jane13439:jane13439-math-0002) and log10(early hibernation colony size) with an additive or interactive effect of species and site as a random effect.

column32: For all statistical analyses, we used R (v. 4.1.2, R Core Team, 2019). We used the ‘ggplot2’ package for data visualization (Wickham, 2016) and the ‘tidyverse’ package for tidying and formatting the data (Wickham et al., 2019). We used the ‘lme4’ (Bates et al., 2015) and ‘marked’ (Laake et al., 2013) packages for data analysis with support of the ‘vegan’ package to calculate the Levins' index, the ‘PerformanceAnalytics’ package (Peterson & Carl, 2020) to assess correlations, the ‘DHARMa’ package to assess model fit of models with binomial distribution (Hartig, 2022), the ‘ggeffects’ package to obtain marginal effects (Lüdecke, 2018), and the ‘R2ucare’ for goodness-of-fit analysis for the CJS model analysis (Gimenez et al., 2017). All continuous variables were centred around the mean.

column13:
STATEMENT ON INCLUSION
Our study brings together authors from a number of different countries, including scientists based in the country where the study was carried out. All authors were engaged early on with the research and study design to ensure that the diverse sets of perspectives they represent was considered from the onset. Whenever relevant, literature published by scientists from the region was cited; efforts were made to consider relevant work published in the local language.

I chose the later, based on the fact that they originate from different places.

Copying and pasting the comment I leave in Discord


Hi folks, I handling a very confusing paper. I'll share the workflow to explain why I'm confused

Data availability statement declares that data and code are available in Zenodo.
I checked the Zenodo and I successfully found  the code but not the data. So, no data (fine 👍  )
Then, I tried to open the R script - a file called "eawp-data.R". It didn't open.
then (plot twist)...I renamed "eawp-data.R" to "eawp-data.Rdata" and it is actually the data!

It took me a lot of time to figureout this workflow

column32: To be able to use all observations in our statistical analyses, we used predictive mean matching, implemented in the mice r package (Buuren & Groothuis-Oudshoorn, 2011) to impute these missing values based on the variables included in the SEM model. The PCA was performed on the correlation matrix of the litter traits using the vegan package (Oksanen et al., 2019). The dimension of forest floor properties (quantitative, ordinal and nominal) was reduced through a Gower dissimilarity-based PCoA, performed with the ape package (Paradis & Schliep, 2018). Because of the many zero values present in the earthworm biomass data, all relations with biomass as a response variable were modelled with zero-inflated-mixed models (ZIMM) with Gaussian error distribution using the nbzimm package. The GAMM was performed with the mgcv package. The SEMs were fit using the lavaan package (Rosseel, 2012).Because zero-inflated models with Gaussian error distribution cannot yet be incorporated in the mgcv and lavaan packages. The dimension of forest floor properties (quantitative, ordinal and nominal) was reduced through a Gower dissimilarity-based PCoA, performed with the ape package (Paradis & Schliep, 2018).

column32: For each hypothesis, an a priori set of mixed models was constructed that included terms for clade (amphibian, reptile or arthropod), latitude and their interaction using the glmm function in the lme4 package in r (R Development Core Team 2012). AICc scores were used to compare models given our small sample sizes relative to the number of parameters estimated in our mixed models (Anderson et al. 2001).

column32:
We characterised the niche of the Italian crayfish across all three periods and the current niches of the red swamp and signal crayfish according to the procedure of Broennimann et al. (2012), using the ecospat R package (Broennimann et al., 2022).

To check whether the observed niche overlap was significantly different from random expectations, we performed equivalence and similarity tests (Warren et al., 2008) using the ecospat R package

column7: The manuscript uses qualitative data in the form of transcribed interviews approximately 1.5 h in length, and some 15–20 pages long. Because of the situated nature of the interview situation, the identifying information available in the unabridged transcripts, and not having asked our respondents to make their interviews publicly available at the time of collection, these are not uploaded to a public repository. The transcripts, which are in Swedish, may be available upon request by contacting the authors and specifying clearly intended purpose and use and with adherence to stringent anonymization procedures.

Not actual issues, but I made the following assumptions based on Discord discussion.
(1) General-Q7: YES. Paper has data, archived for public use, upon request, but is embargoed. Availability statement provides instruction to access the data.
(2) Code-Q01: NO. Authors use MARK software (a GUI interface). There are no references in the text about the use of any programming language for the main analysis.

column32: To investigate the interrelatedness between our ecological variables, we computed Goodman and Kruskal's tau statistic in the r package GoodmanKruskal (Pearson, 2016). We estimated character history by implementing stochastic character mapping in the r package phytools (Revell, 2012). we fit four different univariate models of continuous trait evolution (single optima Brownian motion [BM1], multirate Brownian motion [BMS], single optima Ornstein–Uhlenbeck (OU) [OU1] and multimodal OU [OUM]), using the r package OUwie (Beaulieu & O'Meara, 2016). To estimate the variance in morphology that can be explained by the ecological variables, we computed urn:x-wiley:00218790:media:jane13169:jane13169-math-0001 values using the r package rr2 (Ives & Li, 2018).Using the r package geiger (Harmon, Weir, Brock, Glor, & Challenger, 2008),

column7: Individual encounter histories for both species of giant petrels are available here: Dryad entry: https://doi.org/10.5061/dryad.37qt6nm (Gianuca et al., 2019). Data on climate indexes were obtained from the Climate Diagnostics Centre of NOAA (http://www.cdc.noaa.gov/people/cathy.smith/best/) and the Climate Prediction Centre of NOAA (http://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/). Atmospheric and oceanographic data were obtained from MODIS (http://www.science.oregonstate.edu/ocean.productivity), SeaWiFS (https://oceancolor.gsfc.nasa.gov/data/seawifs/) and QuickSCAT/ASCAT (http://cersat.ifremer.fr/data/products/catalogue) databases. Krill data are available in Fielding et al., (2014). Publicly available fishery effort data were downloaded directly from ICCAT (https://www.iccat.int/en/t2ce.asp) or are provided in Tuck et al. (2015a): Dryad entry: https://doi.org/10.5061/dryad.7f63m (Tuck et al., 2015b). Data from several fisheries agencies are commercially sensitive and have not been archived, but can be requested through the agency data managers: CCAMLR (www.ccamlr.org/), Falkland Islands (www.fis.com/falklandfish). The giant petrel tracking data can be downloaded from the BirdLife International Seabird Tracking Database (http://seabirdtracking.org/mapper/contributor.php?contributor_xml:id=361; dataset ids: 497, 498, 499, 500, 1,385, 1,392, 1,393).

column59:
Not a problem, but when I first looked at the dataset, it seemed complete. However, once I opened the R script, I found the following line:

TRYdata <- fread("5052.txt", header = T, sep = "\t", dec = ".", quote = "", data.table = T)

This suggests that a file, "5052.txt," is necessary but is not available with the data. It may have been generated by other scripts, but this is not mentioned on the Figshare page, which serves as the README.

column55: "P2C2M.GMYC" is a fully wrapped R package complete with documentation, although the code is fully uncommented. It was stated in the paper to only be on GitHub, and is downloadable and installable from GitHub. Version 1.0 was released in 2020 alongside the paper and remains the most up-to-date version, last push was 5 years ago. If searched on CRAN, apparently it was previously available but has since been "removed from the CRAN repository... formerly available versions can be obtained from the archive".

column32: All analyses were conducted in R version 4.0.2 (R Core Team, 2020). Data wrangling was performed using the dplyr package version 1.1.3 (Wickham et al., 2023), Dirichlet regressions were performed in the package DirichletReg verson 0.7–1 (Maier, 2014), GLMMs were constructed in the package glmmTMB version 1.0.2.1 (Brooks et al., 2017) and model fit assessed using performance version 0.5.1, including Nagelkerke's pseudo R2 for Dirichlet models (Lüdecke et al., 2021). Pseudo R2-values for GLMMs were obtained using the MuMIn package version 1.47.5 (Bartoń, 2023). Model predictions were derived using the ggeffects package version 0.16.0 (Lüdecke, 2018) and plotted with ggplot2 version 3.3.2 (Wickham, 2016).

column32: The relationship between count data responses (species richness of all woody plants, ADF, SFF, LFF and not-assigned plants) and explanatory variables including the five variables and four interaction terms, i.e. age of lava flow × (isolation + elevation + precipitation + area), was analysed using GLMs with a Poisson distribution (O’Hara & Kotze, 2010). Using a type-II analysis of deviance, we dropped the non-significant terms for each GLM. We used the Moran eigenvector filtering function (r package spdep) to account for possible effects of spatial autocorrelation on parameter estimates (Bivand et al., 2015). Pseudo-R2 of GLMs were calculated by the relationship ‘1 − residual deviance/null deviance’.

column7:
Climatic data (average relative humidity and minimum temperature) were collected from the Brazilian public repository ‘Meteorological database for education and research’ (banco de dados meteorológicos para ensino e pesquisa) available at the BDMEP website for several cities of Brazil (period 2005–2016). These data are free to access, use and archive (conditions at INMET website). The climatic data used are made available on Figshare https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.c.4485503 (Louren¸co, 2019).
WorldClim V2 global data (Fick & Hijmans, 2017) were downloaded from a public repository online (https://www.worldclim.org/). Updated in July 2016, these data contain average monthly climatic measurements, representative of the period 1970–2000. The spatial resolution used for the maps of Brazil and South America was of 10 minutes (urn:x-wiley:2041210X:media:mee313205:mee313205-math-0047). The spatial resolution used for the maps of Honduras was 2.5 minutes (urn:x-wiley:2041210X:media:mee313205:mee313205-math-0048). These data are not made available in this manuscript due to license restrictions, but are publicly available at WorldClim webpage (https://www.worldclim.org/). See Supporting Information S2 Text for more details.
Dengue notification data (by clinical evaluation, not molecularly confirmed) were obtained from the Brazilian ministry of health, available at the TABNET webportal. These notification data included the total number of dengue cases per month, per year, over the period 2007–2012 for the main municipality of each city. The data used are made available on Figshare https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.c.4485503 (Louren¸co, 2019).
Dengue and chikungunya incidence from Tegucigalpa (city) for the year 2015 were taken from the study by Zambrano et al. (2017) with permission from Elsevier (license number 4576391190534). Counts were collected by the national surveillance system and refer to cases clinically and laboratory confirmed (by serology and RT-PCR). Data series were extracted from Figure 5 using Engauge Digitizer Software V10.4 (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.2585387).
Zika incidence from Tegucigalpa (city) for the year 2016 is the same as in our previous study by Thézé et al. (2018). Counts refer to suspected, not confirmed cases. The data used are made available on Figshare https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.c.4485503 (Louren¸co, 2019).
Aedes aegypti suitability score for Tegucigalpa (city) and Honduras (country level) is the same as in our previous study by Thézé et al. (2018). The data used are made available on Figshare https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.c.4485503 (Louren¸co, 2019).
Climate data (minimum temperature and humidity 2005–2013) per day for Tegucigalpa (city) was obtained from the National Centers for Environmental Information of the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration (NCDC NOAA) (free to be accessed at https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov). The weather station ID was 78720099999, located at the Toncontin International Airport. The data used are made available on Figshare https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.c.4485503 (Louren¸co, 2019).

column7: All data used in this manuscript were obtained from publicly available sources. Maximum dispersal distances are available from Tamme et al. (2014). Traits are available from the KEW Seed Information Database (Royal Botanic Gardens Kew, 2016, available from http://data.kew.org/sid/), the TRY Plant Trait Database (Kattge et al., 2011, version 3.0, available from https://www.try-db.org), and the LEDA Traitbase (Kleyer et al., 2008, available from http://www.uni-oldenburg.de/en/biology/landeco/research/projects/leda/). Demographic information is available from the COMPADRE Plant Matrix Database (Salguero-Gómez et al., 2015, available from http://www.compadredb.org/). Taxonomic information was obtained from The Taxonomic Name Resolution Service using all available data sources (Boyle et al., 2013; The Taxonomic Name Resolution Service), including Tropicos (Missouri Botanical Garden), USDA (USDA, NRCS), Global Composite Checklist (Flann, 2009), The Plant List (2013), and International Legume Database and Information Service, and the Angiosperm Phylogeny Group III (available from http://www.mobot.org/MOBOT/research/APweb/).

column32:
We obtained a phylogeny by trimming down the tree made available by Zanne et al. (2014) to the number of species used in each analysis using the package ape (Paradis, Claude, & Strimmer, 2004) in r (R Core Team, 2017).
We used parallel analysis to simulate 95th percentile eigenvalues from 100 simulated analyses and determine the number of retained principal components (Franklin, Gibson, Robertson, Pohlmann, & Fralish, 1995; Horn, 1965) using the function f a.parallel in the psych package (Revelle, 2017) in r (R Core Team, 2017).
To control for non-independence among lineages in our study, we conducted a phylogenetically informed PCA using the package phytools (Revell, 2012) in r (R Core Team, 2017).
For each PCA, we used the imputePCA function of the missMDA (Josse & Husson, 2016) package in r (R Core Team, 2017) to impute missing values. For the of 141 species, a total of 8.2% (116) of the 1,410 possible trait values were missing.
To examine whether a plant's mode of dispersal, growth form and matrix dimension (i.e. life cycle complexity) explain the location of a species along the major principal components, we used an ANOVA with Type 1 SS (Hector, Von Felten, & Schmid, 2010) including matrix dimension, dispersal mode, growth form and their two-way interactions as predictors (function aov in r, R Core Team, 2017).
To ensure our results were not affected by statistical dependence among the principal components, we conducted a permutational ANOVA on the first three principal components using Euclidian distance and 9,999 permutations with the function adonis in the package vegan (Oksanen et al., 2017) in r (R Core Team, 2017). As the results for the permutational ANOVA (Table S9) were the same as the results for the ANOVA, we report the results obtained from the ANOVA here. All analyses were conducted in r (R Core Team, 2017).

column32:
Consequently, a principal coordinate analysis (PCoA) based on Gower distances was performed with the trait matrix using the ape package in R (Paradis & Schliep, 2018). 
A logistic regression was fitted for each pond considering the sampling time as a random effect—package ‘glmmTMB’ of R (Magnusson et al., 2017). 
Functional diversity was quantified by a set of community-level complementary indices with the FD package (Laliberté & Legendre, 2010; Laliberté et al., 2014). 
Path analyses were performed with the lavaan package in R (Rosseel, 2012).

Code is available as supplementary. This information is only described under "Usage notes" of archived data in Dryad:
The data files in this package are designed to be read into an R script that is a supplemental document published with the paper with which this data archive is associated.  Running this R script will read in the data files, and then run all analyses and generate all output that are used in this paper. The ReadMe file associated with this archive describes all of the variables in the data tables within this data archive. Note that there are 2 versions of this ReadMe document: (1) an ASCII text version that should be universally readable, and (2) a PDF version for which formatting will make the contents more comprehensible by anyone who can view the contents of the PDF version.

column32: (1) Each of the aforementioned TCH and SDTCH models was identified from the full set of predictors by finding the three candidate models with the lowest AICc values using the glmulti package (Calcagno, 2020), then selecting the one with the lowest root mean square error and highest adjusted R2 based on leave-one-out cross-validation (caret package; Kuhn, 2020) as the final model. (2)  To do this, we used the support vector machine binary classifier (Vapnik, 1998) as implemented for Python in Scikit-learn (https://scikit-learn.org/stable/; program available at https://github.com/Curran-WFU) to make predictive models of residual vegetation state for landslides aged 6–25 years.

column13:
INCLUSION STATEMENT
Our study brings together authors from different countries, including scientists based in the country where the study was carried out. All authors were engaged early on with the research and study design to ensure that the diverse sets of perspectives they represent was considered from the onset. Whenever relevant, literature published by scientists from the region was cited. Preliminary results were presented by the authors to local authors and research institutions.

We conducted a Tukey's HSD test in the agricolae package (de Mendiburu, 2014) to evaluate differences among means.

column32: We formulate a model for jointly optimizing the selection of river protected areas and barrier removals. Given a set of biodiversity elements (i.e., habitat classes) in need of conservation, the aim of the model is to maximize longitudinal connectivity between selected areas through targeted barrier removals, subject to lower/upper limits on the amounts of protected habitat and a cap on the number of barrier removals.

column13: Data come from public or private datasets but there is no real sampling data "We explored the influence of J, Ω and DR on spatial and temporal TL slopes for 82 empirical population matrices. The matrices were based on annual time series of total counts for 20 species of aphid (Supporting Information Table S1) sampled for 35 years in 11 locations in the UK (Supporting Information Figure S1; 20 matrices, termed the “aphid matrices”); annual time series of counts for 22 plankton groups (Supporting Information Table S1) sampled for 56 years in 26 regions in seas around the UK (Supporting Information Figure S2; 22 matrices, termed the “plankton matrices”); and chlorophyll-a concentration time series measured at several locations at each of 10 depths (Supporting Information Table S1) in four distance categories (here called “groups”) from the coast of Southern California over 28 years."
column16: The aphid and plankton data used for this study can be obtained after getting permission from the data owners, the Rothamsted Insect Survey and the Sir Alister Hardy Foundation for Ocean Science, which is part of the Marine Biological Association of the UK. column32: The average multifunctionality, multiple threshold multifunctionality and turnover approaches were calculated using the ‘multifunc’ package (Byrnes et al., 2014). We calculated the correlation strength among ecosystem variables to down-weight highly correlated functions. e investigated the relationships of the overall multitrophic richness (all trophic groups) and simplified multitrophic richness (excluding each trophic group at each step) with the different multifunctionality indexes (averaging multifunctionality and five multifunctional thresholds) using linear mixed-effect models (LMEs) available in the package nlme (Pinheiro et al., 2013). As we had many trophic groups, we reduced the number of trophic groups in the pSEM using Akaike information criteria corrected for small sample size (AICc), which is implemented in the piecewiseSEM package (Lefcheck, 2016). The pSEM was fitted using a linear mixed-effect model in the piecewiseSEM package, with seasons nested within years within each lake as random factor.

column59:
The archived data is substantially complete for its intended modeling purpose: it contains individual capture histories, disease states (for the two viruses), metadata, session timing, and individual covariates (weight, etc.) across 17 years.
However, it is not absolutely complete in the sense of being everything collected. Some data remain under control of the institutional owner (Biosecurity SA).

column7:
The datasets generated during and analysed during the current study are available via the Dryad Digital Repository https://doi.org/10.5061/dryad.5vn554c (Jones et al., 2018).
Although field data are made available, geographic location is masked to protect grower privacy. The raw reads are achieved in Sequences Read Archives (SRA) of NCBI with SRA accession SRP126862. Model code for the entire pipeline of the 16S rDNA sequencing analyses is available via Zenodo https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.2557792 (Fu, 2019).

column7: Full data have not been archived according to the BES data archiving policy due to restrictions from the data owners. Below we indicate where and how to obtain data that were not archived. Species ranges for mammals and amphibians can be downloaded from https://www.iucnredlist.org/resources/spatial-data-download. Plant polygons are available in the repository https://tinyurl.com/y7zxzxhv. Bird distribution ranges have to be requested at http://datazone.birdlife.org/species/requestdis. Habitat preferences for vertebrates, including altitudinal ranges, can be downloaded from http://apiv3.iucnredlist.org/api/v3/docs after requesting a token in http://apiv3.iucnredlist.org/api/v3/token. The rest of the data used in this study (land cover and boundary data for Brazil, digital elevation map, soy expansion data) and r code are available at https://doi.org/10.5061/dryad.nvx0k6dpd (Durán et al., 2020).

column7:
Package documentation includes a short guide to the use, multiple models and multiple species calculation of TP and can be found in the supplementary material (Appendices S1–S3), and vignettes included within the package (browseVignettes(“tRophicPosition”)). An expanded description and r code of the examples and figures generated in this manuscript can be found in supplementary material S4 and S5, respectively.

tRophicPosition is under active development. Future versions of the package will include different methods and hierarchical models including the use of scaled TDFs (Hussey et al., 2014) and the estimation of consumer TP from amino acid δ15N (Bradley et al., 2015) that include variation in TDF and β. The development version is freely available in GitHub (https://github.com/clquezada/tRophicPosition), while the stable version (currently 0.7.5) can be found in CRAN (https://cran.r-project.org/package=tRophicPosition).

column59:
Admittedly, I did struggle to fill in this entry as they used a preexisting dataset but did not link the code they used or their modified dataset. Therefore, could you please take a look at it, if you can?
Also, they used two 'datasets': the Project Gutenburg Corpus which is a storing of many pieces of literature typed into the dataset, and a list of terms for species that they got from Wikispecies and Wikimedia. It seems that they only linked to Project Gutenburg, did not link to where they got their species list, and did not archive their filtered Gutenburg dataset or their filtered taxon term list. 
They also did not say how they actually filtered and analysed the datasets. The Project Gutenburg websites seem to say how to do so by code but they are not directly referenced.

I am not sure where I should have written this but as this is the last paper I will be able to analyse, I needed to give a word on how long it took me to analyse each paper:
It would take me a few hours for each paper. Papers that did archive their data, code and READMEs took the longest, compared to those that did not. 
What took longest was comparing the archived data to the methods as it involved meticulously reading the methods to ensure absolutely all the necessary data to reproduce the results were there. Evaluating the READMEs and annotations also took long, though not nearly as long.    
The amount of time I took is because I am unfortunately an outlier with ADHD, which makes reading anything, especially the thick complex texts of academic papers, quite difficult.

column7: All data and Mothra code are archived on Zenodo and iCollections images are accessible via the NHM data portal. Mothra code are available in Feng et al. (2021): https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.5551110. Mothra training data, including the networks trained and images used in training are available in de Siqueira (2021): https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.6066153. The results of Mothra measurements of all iCollections butterflies are available in Price and Fenberg (2021): https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.5759758. All data used for Figures 3-6, Figures S1–S2 and the supplementary information tables are available in Wilson et al. (2022): https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.6066070. All images used are part of the iCollections project (Paterson et al., 2016) and are freely available on the NHM data portal: https://doi.org/10.5519/0038559
